CD rarely manifests with bloody diarrhea and is more often associated with weight loss and malnourishment.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-week history of colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has bowel movements 10–12 times daily; the stool contains blood and mucus. He constantly has the urge to defecate. Examination of the abdomen shows diffuse tenderness to palpation. Serum concentration of C-reactive protein is 20 mg/L (N < 10). Colonoscopy shows a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps. This patient's condition puts him at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a thrombotic microangiopathy caused by bacterial toxins, most commonly the Shiga-like toxin of enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (E. coli) O157:H7. HUS mainly occurs in children < 5 years of age with a classic triad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and impaired renal function all occurring 5–10 days after the onset of a diarrheal illness. It is not a complication of ulcerative colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis is typically associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis) but ulcerative colitis (UC) is not among them. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), however, is associated with ulcerative colitis, as well as Crohn disease (CD). Approximately 5% of patients with UC and < 5% of patients with CD develop PSC over their lifetime. Of the patients who have PSC, approximately 90% have inflammatory bowel disease (∼ 87% have UC and ∼ 13% have CD).

C) CORRECT:

Patients with ulcerative colitis have an increased risk of colorectal cancer, with the extent, duration, and histologic severity of the disease correlating with the degree of risk. Eight to ten years after the initial diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, patients should receive colonoscopies with biopsies every 1–5 years to screen for colorectal cancer. Colorectal cancer in ulcerative colitis patients is more likely to arise from non-polypoid lesions and to be multifocal.

D) INCORRECT:

Colonic granulomas are often seen in Crohn disease, an inflammatory bowel disease that also causes abdominal cramping and diarrhea. Unlike ulcerative colitis, which only affects the colon and rectum, Crohn disease can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus (most commonly involved site is the terminal ileum). However, Crohn disease usually spares the rectum and typically features grossly nonbloody diarrhea (although stool is often positive for occult blood). In addition, ileocolonoscopy in a patient with active Crohn disease would more likely show linear ulcers, pinpoint lesions, a characteristic cobblestone appearance of the mucosa, and perianal fissures or fistulas.

E) INCORRECT:

Recurrent urinary tract infections can be a complication of Crohn disease (CD), not ulcerative colitis (UC). Transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract distinguishes CD from UC, which predisposes individuals to the development of fistulas. An enterovesical fistula is an abnormal connection between the bowel and bladder. This connection leads to the introduction of infectious bacteria to the bladder and subsequently the development of urinary tract infections.
questions.hint: The patient presents with colicky abdominal pain and bloody, mucoid diarrhea. Serum studies show an elevated inflammatory marker, and colonoscopy shows a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps. These symptoms and findings are consistent with a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 3-week history of loose stools. He has 2–3 episodes of loose stools a day that are occasionally bloody. During this period, he has also had crampy abdominal pain, generalized fatigue, and a 2-kg (5-lb) weight loss. Vital signs are within normal limits. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,400/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 14 mm/h. A colonoscopy shows a friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact with the endoscope. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A gluten-free diet is indicated as a diagnostic and therapeutic option in patients with suspected or confirmed celiac disease (CD). Although recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fatigue are also seen in patients with CD, bloody stools and inflamed, friable rectal mucosa on colonoscopy are not features of this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Proctocolectomy is an elective surgery for patients with refractory UC, medication-induced side effects, and increased risk of malignancy (e.g., those with dysplastic polyps). Emergency proctocolectomy is indicated in patients with life-threatening complications due to UC such as toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, or massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Since this adolescent has features of mild UC, has not yet received a trial of medical therapy, and has no symptoms of complications due to UC, a proctocolectomy is not the appropriate treatment at this time.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has mild UC, the criteria for which are < 4 stools/day (that can occasionally be bloody) and no signs of systemic illness such as fever, tachycardia, hemoglobin ≤ 11.5 g/dL, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate ≥ 30 mm/h (see “Truelove and Witts severity index” table). The first-line treatment for mild UC limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon is rectal 5-aminosalicylic acid derivatives (5-ASAs) such as mesalamine. Rectal 5-ASAs are more effective in inducing remission than rectal glucocorticoids, and they have fewer side effects. Patients who cannot tolerate rectal medications or who have extensive disease (i.e., extending proximal to the splenic flexure) can be treated with oral 5-ASAs.

See “Medications for induction of remission in ulcerative colitis” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoid therapy (e.g., oral prednisone) is often used to induce remission in ambulatory patients with severely active UC, which is defined as having > 6 bloody stools/day with signs of systemic illness (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hemoglobin < 10.5 g/dL, elevated inflammatory markers). Oral glucocorticoids may also be indicated in patients with mild or moderate UC who have not responded to first-line treatment and topical glucocorticoids. As this patient has features of mild UC and has not received first-line treatment, systemic glucocorticoid therapy is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-TNF-α therapy (e.g., infliximab) can be used to induce and maintain remission in patients with moderate to severe UC. This patient has mild UC (defined as having < 4 stools/day and no signs of systemic illness), for which anti-TNF-α therapy is not indicated.
questions.hint: Bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain raise concern for ulcerative colitis (UC). Colonoscopy findings of friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact support this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of increasing generalized fatigue. He has also had mild cramping lower abdominal pain and occasionally bloody diarrhea for the past 5 weeks. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a soft and nondistended abdomen with slight tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants bilaterally. Rectal examination shows stool mixed with blood. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Colonoscopy with biopsy is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of IBD. In contrast to CD, which may affect the entire gastrointestinal tract but typically spares the rectum, UC usually affects only the colon and rectum in a continuous pattern. Typical macroscopic findings in UC include an inflamed, reddened mucosa, bleeding on contact with the endoscope, fibrin-covered ulcers, and loss of vascular markings. Histological findings include granulocyte infiltration to the mucosa and submucosa, crypt abscesses, and, in advanced disease, mucosal atrophy and epithelial dysplasia.

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in patients with features of acute severe disease, defined as > 6 bloody stools per day and/or signs of systemic toxicity (fever, tachycardia, anemia, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate), because of an increased risk of bowel perforation. Instead, a lower endoscopy (sigmoidoscopy) may be attempted to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment. In these patients, a full colonoscopy should be performed once their condition has improved.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the sigmoid colon

The mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Several linear, semi-confluent ulcerations (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy may be used to evaluate for IBD and is the diagnostic test of choice in patients with acute severe disease who have an increased risk of bowel perforation. As this patient has features of mild IBD (e.g., mild abdominal pain; no fever, tachycardia, or anemia; normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and requires evaluation of the entire colon to assess the extent of disease, sigmoidoscopy is not the most appropriate initial test.

C) INCORRECT:

A D-xylose absorption test is indicated to diagnose malabsorption syndrome, which may be caused by disorders such as celiac disease, Whipple disease, or IBD and manifests with fatigue, chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. However, this patient does not have steatorrhea or weight loss, which makes malabsorption unlikely. Additionally, a D-xylose absorption test is neither routinely conducted nor recommended as an initial test if there is a strong suspicion of UC.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis can be useful for differentiating between UC and CD. However, it is neither routinely conducted nor recommended as an initial test if there is a strong suspicion of UC.

Although the role of CT in the diagnosis of uncomplicated UC is limited, this imaging modality is helpful for diagnosing complications associated with this disease (e.g., toxic megacolon, perforation).

E) INCORRECT:

Although capsule endoscopy may help to visualize typical lesions of UC, its role in the diagnosis of the disease is limited because it does not allow tissue samples to be taken for biopsy.

Capsule endoscopy may be used in cases of obscure gastrointestinal bleeding. Although this patient presents with bloody diarrhea, he also has fatigue, abdominal pain, and elevated inflammatory markers, which are more suggestive of UC.
questions.hint: This patient has findings suggestive of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Although the two principal types of IBD, Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), have similar features, the presence of bloody diarrhea indicates UC as the most likely cause of symptoms. CD rarely manifests with bloody diarrhea and is more often associated with weight loss and malnourishment.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-month history of persistent abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and rectal pain. During the past 2 weeks, she has had up to 4 small volumed, blood-tinged stools with mucus daily. She has also had intermittent fevers and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during this time. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant with guarding but no rebound. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a granular, hyperemic, and friable rectal mucosa that bleeds easily on contact. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a thrombotic microangiopathy and complication of diarrheal bacterial infection, particularly with enterohemorrhagic E. coli. Though this patient has a 1-month history of diarrhea, the typical presentation of HUS is the triad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and impaired renal function that develops 5–10 days after the onset of diarrheal illness. Additionally, HUS typically affects young children.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastric cancer has multiple risk factors, but ulcerative colitis, which this patient likely has, is not among them. Risk factors for gastric cancer include a diet rich in nitrates and salt, alcohol use, Helicobacter pylori infection, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.

C) CORRECT:

This patient likely has ulcerative colitis (UC), which is characterized by episodes of bloody diarrhea with mucus, tenesmus, and crampy abdominal pain, in combination with endoscopic findings of an inflamed, friable mucosa with rectal involvement. Individuals with UC have an increased risk of colorectal cancer, with risk factors including the extent of colitis, the duration of disease, and the histological severity of inflammation. Therefore, they should undergo surveillance colonoscopies with biopsies every 1–5 years to screen for colorectal cancer starting 8–10 years after initial diagnosis of UC.

D) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic cancer has multiple risk factors, but ulcerative colitis, which this patient likely has, is not among them. Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include smoking, heavy alcohol consumption, chronic pancreatitis, and inherited genetic syndromes.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonic granulomas can develop in patients with Crohn disease (CD), an inflammatory bowel disease that also causes abdominal cramping and diarrhea. Colonic granulomas have low sensitivity but high specificity for CD. However, in CD, the rectum is usually spared and it mostly presents with watery, nonbloody stools and with just a slight increase in stool frequency as opposed to this patient showing bloody stools with mucus and a marked increase in stool frequency. Furthermore, right lower quadrant pain is more common in CD.
questions.hint: If a biopsy were conducted, histopathology would show mucosal and submucosal inflammation with crypt abscesses.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with a 10-week history of bloody diarrhea mixed with mucus and occasional abdominal cramping. He reports low-grade fevers, fatigue, and joint pain in his knees over the past few weeks. He has had no recent travel or antibiotic use, and over-the-counter analgesics have provided minimal relief. Examination shows mild left lower quadrant tenderness without guarding (see lab results).


Blood pressure
110/70 mmHg


Temperature
37.8°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
110 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


C-reactive peptide
20 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


Stool




 Stool culture
Normal
No growth of pathogenic bacteria



Colonoscopy is planned. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infectious colitis usually presents acutely and resolves within days to weeks. The 10-week duration of symptoms, negative stool culture, and systemic features such as joint pain and anemia suggest a chronic inflammatory process rather than an acute infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional disorder without objective signs of inflammation. The presence of bloody diarrhea, systemic symptoms, and laboratory abnormalities such as anemia and elevated C-reactive protein indicate an inflammatory condition, not a functional motility disorder like irritable bowel syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis manifests with bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and systemic symptoms such as low-grade fever and joint pain. The disease is characterized by continuous mucosal inflammation starting in the rectum and extending proximally. Laboratory findings of anemia and elevated C-reactive protein further support an inflammatory process. The absence of pathogenic bacteria in stool cultures rules out an infectious cause. Colonoscopy would reveal the continuous pattern of inflammation, confirming the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Ulcerative colitis is characterized by chronic bloody diarrhea with mucus, anemia due to chronic blood loss, and can have extraintestinal manifestations such as joint pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease typically presents with skip lesions and transmural inflammation, often affecting the terminal ileum and right colon. It rarely causes continuous, bloody diarrhea. The left lower quadrant tenderness and bloody diarrhea with mucus suggest superficial mucosal inflammation, which is more consistent with ulcerative colitis than Crohn disease.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man presents with a three-week history of bloody diarrhea, lower abdominal cramping, and urgency. He reports 6–8 bowel movements daily, often with nocturnal episodes. He denies recent travel or antibiotic use. On examination, he appears mildly dehydrated. Rectal examination reveals bright red blood. Stool cultures for bacteria and parasites are negative.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ischemic colitis usually affects older adults with vascular risk factors and presents acutely. It often spares the rectum due to its rich blood supply. The patient's age, chronic symptom duration, and rectal bleeding make ischemic colitis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis manifests with chronic mucosal inflammation confined to the colon, starting at the rectum and spreading proximally. The patient's symptoms, including frequent bloody diarrhea, lower abdominal cramping, urgency, and nocturnal bowel movements, indicate a mucosal inflammatory process disrupting colonic function. Negative stool cultures for bacteria and parasites support an inflammatory rather than infectious etiology. This condition leads to superficial ulcerations and mucosal friability, confirmed by endoscopy and histopathology showing crypt distortion and inflammatory infiltrate.

Key learning point: Ulcerative colitis is characterized by bloody diarrhea, urgency, and abdominal pain, typically affecting the colon and rectum, and is a common cause of these symptoms in young individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

Infectious colitis typically presents acutely and is associated with risk factors like recent travel or antibiotic use. The patient's prolonged symptoms and negative stool cultures for bacteria and parasites suggest a noninfectious inflammatory process.

D) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease can present with inflammatory bowel symptoms in young adults, but it typically involves patchy, transmural inflammation with skip lesions, fistulae, and perianal disease. The continuous bloody diarrhea and rectal bleeding suggest a diffuse mucosal process, not characteristic of Crohn disease.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with six weeks of watery diarrhea alternating with bloody stools, diffuse lower abdominal cramping, and mild urgency. He reports intermittent similar episodes over the past year. Examination shows tenderness in the left lower quadrant without rebound tenderness. Laboratory tests reveal mild normocytic anemia and elevated C-reactive protein. Stool studies for pathogens are negative (see report).
Flexible sigmoidoscopy: Continuous mucosal erythema and superficial ulcerations extending from the rectum to the sigmoid colon, with raised inflamed areas of mucosa and no skip lesions
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis manifests with chronic, relapsing symptoms such as watery diarrhea mixed with blood, lower abdominal cramping, and urgency. The patient's history of intermittent episodes over the past year aligns with this inflammatory bowel disease's chronic course. Endoscopic findings of continuous mucosal erythema and superficial ulcerations from the rectum to the sigmoid colon are characteristic of ulcerative colitis, which involves mucosal and submucosal inflammation. Laboratory findings, including mild normocytic anemia and elevated C-reactive protein, support an inflammatory process. Negative stool studies exclude infectious causes, reinforcing the diagnosis based on clinical and endoscopic features.

Key learning point: Ulcerative colitis is characterized by continuous colonic inflammation, often with bloody diarrhea, and can present with a 'lead-pipe' appearance on barium enema and pseudopolyps on colonoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome presents with intermittent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits but lacks inflammatory markers. The presence of bloody stools, elevated C-reactive protein, and normocytic anemia suggests an inflammatory process. Endoscopic findings of continuous mucosal erythema and ulcerations are inconsistent with irritable bowel syndrome, which typically shows normal mucosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease can present with chronic diarrhea and abdominal discomfort. However, it typically shows patchy inflammation with skip lesions and transmural involvement, often sparing the rectum. The continuous mucosal involvement from the rectum to the sigmoid colon without skip lesions is inconsistent with Crohn disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious colitis might present with watery and bloody diarrhea, but it usually resolves within days to weeks. The chronic symptom duration and negative stool studies argue against an infectious cause. Endoscopic findings of continuous mucosal erythema and superficial ulcerations are not typical of infectious colitis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with six days of worsening bloody diarrhea, over 10 bowel movements per day, and severe lower abdominal pain. He has a 6-year history of ulcerative colitis. He appears fatigued. He has not responded to oral medications and supportive measures (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
112/min


Temperature
38.5°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
98 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


C-reactive peptide
15 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L



Abdominal X-ray: No evidence of perforation
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous infliximab, a TNF-alpha inhibitor, is used for moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis refractory to standard therapy. It is typically reserved for cases unresponsive to high-dose intravenous corticosteroids. Using infliximab without first trying IV corticosteroids would prematurely expose the patient to risks associated with powerful immunosuppressants.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose oral 5-aminosalicylic acid is used for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis. In severe flares, the inflammatory burden is too high for its slower onset of action. The patient's severe symptoms and failure to respond to oral medications indicate the need for more potent systemic interventions.

C) INCORRECT:

Total proctocolectomy is reserved for complications like perforation, toxic megacolon, or failure of maximal medical therapy. The patient's abdominal x-ray shows no perforation, and there is no indication of toxic megacolon. The standard approach for severe flares involves intravenous corticosteroids before considering surgery.

D) CORRECT:

In acute severe ulcerative colitis flares, high-dose intravenous corticosteroids are the first-line treatment. They provide potent immunosuppression by reducing inflammatory cytokines and leukocyte migration, crucial for controlling severe mucosal inflammation and systemic symptoms. This approach is indicated in patients with six or more bowel movements per day in addition to at least one systemic sign of toxicity, such as fever, tachycardia, anemia, and/or elevated inflammatory markers. The intravenous route ensures rapid drug delivery, essential for quickly controlling inflammation and preventing complications.

Key learning point: In severe ulcerative colitis flares, intravenous corticosteroids such as methylprednisolone are the treatment of choice to rapidly control inflammation and induce remission.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman with ulcerative colitis presents to the Outpatient Clinic. She has been in clinical remission for six months on a stable dose of mesalamine and reports no symptoms. Her most recent colonoscopy showed only mild residual inflammation. She expresses a desire to become pregnant and is concerned about the impact of her medication on pregnancy outcomes. Laboratory tests are unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing her condition?

choices.text: Delay pregnancy until disease-free for one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are used for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis flares, not for maintenance in remission. This patient is asymptomatic and stable on mesalamine. Corticosteroids have potential adverse effects, including increased infection risk and metabolic disturbances, which could affect pregnancy outcomes.

B) CORRECT:

Mesalamine, a 5-aminosalicylate, is safe during pregnancy and crucial for maintaining remission in ulcerative colitis. Active disease increases risks of preterm delivery, miscarriage, and low birth weight. Continuing mesalamine minimizes flare-ups, reducing the need for potentially harmful medications during pregnancy. Maintaining disease control is essential for maternal and fetal health.

Key learning point: Women with well-controlled ulcerative colitis can conceive and have successful pregnancies; it is important to ensure the disease is in remission or well-controlled before conception to minimize risks.

C) INCORRECT:

Achieving and maintaining clinical remission is the goal for ulcerative colitis patients planning pregnancy. This patient is in remission with mild residual inflammation, and mesalamine is safe during pregnancy. Delaying conception for complete disease-free status is unnecessary and not supported by current recommendations.

D) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing treatment in ulcerative colitis can lead to disease flare-ups, posing risks such as preterm delivery and low birth weight. Mesalamine is safe during pregnancy and helps maintain remission, preventing complications. Stopping treatment could destabilize the patient's condition, compromising maternal and fetal well-being.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of watery diarrhea occasionally containing blood, a 4-kg weight loss, and sporadic lower abdominal pain. He denies recent travel and has no known food intolerances. Physical examination reveals mild left lower quadrant tenderness. Stool cultures and tests for ova and parasites are negative (see lab results).


Heart rate
90/min



Blood pressure
115/75 mm Hg


Temperature
38.0°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
110 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


C-reactive peptide
22 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L



Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Stool test for Clostridioides difficile toxin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Colonoscopy with biopsy is the preferred investigation for suspected ulcerative colitis, as it allows direct visualization of the colonic mucosa and histopathologic evaluation. Endoscopic findings may include continuous inflammation starting at the rectum, mucosal friability, and pseudopolyps. Biopsy can reveal crypt architectural distortion, basal lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates, and crypt abscesses, which are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. This comprehensive assessment confirms the diagnosis and helps determine disease extent, guiding treatment decisions.

Key learning point: Colonoscopy is the most appropriate investigation to establish the diagnosis of inflammatory bowel diseases such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease, as it allows direct visualization and biopsy of the colonic mucosa.

B) INCORRECT:

CT imaging can identify bowel wall thickening and pericolonic inflammation but does not allow direct mucosal visualization or histologic sampling. In chronic diarrheal illness, a test providing both mucosal evaluation and biopsy is preferred over CT, which may only suggest nonspecific inflammatory changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Testing for Clostridioides difficile toxin is relevant in acute antibiotic-associated diarrhea. This patient's chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal pain suggest a chronic inflammatory process rather than an acute infection, and there are no risk factors for C. difficile infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Double-contrast barium enema outlines colonic structure but lacks the ability to provide direct mucosal visualization or histopathologic confirmation. It is less sensitive for early or subtle mucosal changes and cannot detect skip lesions or provide tissue samples, limiting its utility in diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and intermittent diarrhea. He reports a 6-kg weight loss during this period. On examination, he has pale conjunctivae. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the lower quadrants. A photograph from a colonoscopy of the descending colon is provided, with similar findings noted in the sigmoid colon and rectum. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules in the intestinal mucosa are seen in patients with Whipple disease, an infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. Symptoms include diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss due to malabsorption. However, this condition occurs more commonly in elderly men, and colonoscopy would show pale yellow, eroded patches rather than ulcerations.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are present in over 90% of patients with celiac disease (CD). Symptoms of CD can include diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue (due to malabsorption and vitamin deficiencies). However, endoscopy would demonstrate villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia (a smooth or atrophic mucous membrane), not ulcerations. Moreover, CD is a disease of the small intestine, the colon is not typically affected.

C) INCORRECT:

A lactose hydrogen breath test is positive in lactose malabsorption, which is characterized by an inability to digest lactose due to lactase deficiency. Lactose malabsorption also causes diarrhea and abdominal cramps. However, symptoms usually also include bloating and occur after consuming dairy products. Additionally, patients with lactase deficiency have a macroscopically normal colonic mucosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCAs) are associated with inflammatory bowel disease, particularly with Crohn disease (up to 70% of cases). Crohn disease can manifest with nonbloody chronic diarrhea, fatigue, lower abdominal pain, weight loss, and anemia. However, characteristic colonoscopic findings include multiple, sharply delineated areas of inflammation and intervening areas of normal mucosa. The delineated regions coalesce to form long, serpiginous ulcers between normal mucosa, thus giving the mucosa a cobblestone appearance. Small aphthous ulcerations arranged in a longitudinal fashion may also be present. This patient's colonoscopic findings indicate UC, which is associated with ASCAs in only 20% of cases.

E) CORRECT:

Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCAs) are positive in up to 70% of patients with UC, with no correlation between the titer and disease activity. While serologic testing is not recommended for definitive diagnosis or exclusion of UC, it can support the diagnosis. An increase in p-ANCAs is also seen in patients with other inflammatory disorders, including autoimmune systemic vasculitis (especially microscopic polyangiitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Key learning point: Ulcerative colitis is commonly associated with perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) positivity, though this marker is not specific for diagnosis.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the sigmoid colon

The mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Several linear, semi-confluent ulcerations (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.
questions.hint: This patient has symptoms typical of inflammatory bowel disease. Conjunctival pallor indicates anemia, possibly due to chronic gastrointestinal bleeding. The colonoscopy shows continuous mucosal inflammation with fibrin-covered ulcerations and loss of superficial vascular markings, which is highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. He reports having 10–12 bowel movements per day, with blood and mucus in the stool, and a constant urge to defecate. On abdominal examination, there is diffuse tenderness to palpation. His serum C-reactive protein is 20 mg/L (≤ 10). Colonoscopy reveals a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps. This condition puts him at greatest risk of developing which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Recurrent urinary tract infections can be a complication of Crohn disease (CD), not ulcerative colitis (UC). Transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract distinguishes CD from UC, which predisposes individuals to the development of fistulas. An enterovesical fistula is an abnormal connection between the bowel and bladder. This connection leads to the introduction of infectious bacteria to the bladder and subsequently the development of urinary tract infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Colonic granulomas are often seen in Crohn disease, an inflammatory bowel disease that also causes abdominal cramping and diarrhea. Unlike ulcerative colitis, which only affects the colon and rectum, Crohn disease can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus (most commonly involved site is the terminal ileum). However, Crohn disease usually spares the rectum and typically features grossly nonbloody diarrhea (although stool is often positive for occult blood). In addition, ileocolonoscopy in a patient with active Crohn disease would more likely show linear ulcers, pinpoint lesions, a characteristic cobblestone appearance of the mucosa, and perianal fissures or fistulas.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with ulcerative colitis have an increased risk of colorectal cancer, with the extent, duration, and histologic severity of the disease correlating with the degree of risk. Eight to ten years after the initial diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, patients should receive colonoscopies with biopsies every 1–5 years to screen for colorectal cancer. Colorectal cancer in ulcerative colitis patients is more likely to arise from non-polypoid lesions and to be multifocal.

Key learning point: Ulcerative colitis significantly increases the risk of colorectal cancer, necessitating regular colonoscopic surveillance beginning 8–10 years after diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis is typically associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis) but ulcerative colitis (UC) is not among them. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), however, is associated with ulcerative colitis, as well as Crohn disease (CD). Approximately 5% of patients with UC and < 5% of patients with CD develop PSC over their lifetime. Of the patients who have PSC, approximately 90% have inflammatory bowel disease (∼ 87% have UC and ∼ 13% have CD).

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a thrombotic microangiopathy caused by bacterial toxins, most commonly the Shiga-like toxin of enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (E. coli) O157:H7. HUS mainly occurs in children < 5 years of age with a classic triad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and impaired renal function all occurring 5–10 days after the onset of a diarrheal illness. It is not a complication of ulcerative colitis.
questions.hint: The patient presents with colicky abdominal pain and bloody, mucoid diarrhea. Serum studies show an elevated inflammatory marker, and colonoscopy shows a bleeding, ulcerated rectal mucosa with several pseudopolyps. These symptoms and findings are consistent with a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to your clinic with a 3-week history of loose stools, occurring 2–3 times per day and occasionally bloody. He also reports crampy abdominal pain, generalized fatigue, and a 2-kg weight loss during this period. Vital signs are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 131 g/L (125–170), white blood cell count is 12.4 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 14 mm/h (0–10). Colonoscopy reveals friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact with the endoscope. Which one of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-TNF-α therapy (e.g., infliximab) can be used to induce and maintain remission in patients with moderate to severe UC. This patient has mild UC (defined as having < 4 stools/day and no signs of systemic illness), for which anti-TNF-α therapy is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has mild UC, the criteria for which are < 4 stools/day (that can occasionally be bloody) and no signs of systemic illness such as fever, tachycardia, severe anemia, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate ≥ 30 mm/h (see “Truelove and Witts severity index” table). The first-line treatment for mild UC limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon is rectal 5-aminosalicylic acid derivatives (5-ASAs) such as mesalamine. Rectal 5-ASAs are more effective in inducing remission than rectal glucocorticoids, and they have fewer side effects. Patients who cannot tolerate rectal medications or who have extensive disease (i.e., extending proximal to the splenic flexure) can be treated with oral 5-ASAs.

See “Medications for induction of remission in ulcerative colitis” table.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for mild ulcerative colitis is rectal 5-aminosalicylic acid derivatives such as mesalamine, which effectively induce remission with minimal side effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoid therapy (e.g., oral prednisone) is often used to induce remission in ambulatory patients with severely active UC, which is defined as having > 6 bloody stools/day with signs of systemic illness (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hemoglobin < 75% of normal, elevated inflammatory markers). Oral glucocorticoids may also be indicated in patients with mild or moderate UC who have not responded to first-line treatment and topical glucocorticoids. As this patient has features of mild UC and has not received first-line treatment, systemic glucocorticoid therapy is not indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Proctocolectomy is an elective surgery for patients with refractory UC, medication-induced side effects, and increased risk of malignancy (e.g., those with dysplastic polyps). Emergency proctocolectomy is indicated in patients with life-threatening complications due to UC such as toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, or massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Since this adolescent has features of mild UC, has not yet received a trial of medical therapy, and has no symptoms of complications due to UC, a proctocolectomy is not the appropriate treatment at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

A gluten-free diet is indicated as a diagnostic and therapeutic option in patients with suspected or confirmed celiac disease (CD). Although recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fatigue are also seen in patients with CD, bloody stools and inflamed, friable rectal mucosa on colonoscopy are not features of this condition.
questions.hint: Bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain raise concern for ulcerative colitis (UC). Colonoscopy findings of friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact support this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of persistent abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and rectal pain. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had up to 4 small-volume, blood-tinged stools with mucus daily. She also reports intermittent fevers and a 4.5-kg weight loss during this period. On examination, her abdomen is soft with tenderness and guarding in the left lower quadrant, but no rebound. Stool testing is positive for occult blood. Colonoscopy reveals a granular, hyperemic, and friable rectal mucosa that bleeds easily on contact. Which one of the following is she at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient likely has ulcerative colitis (UC), which is characterized by episodes of bloody diarrhea with mucus, tenesmus, and crampy abdominal pain, in combination with endoscopic findings of an inflamed, friable mucosa with rectal involvement. Individuals with UC have an increased risk of colorectal cancer, with risk factors including the extent of colitis, the duration of disease, and the histological severity of inflammation. Therefore, they should undergo surveillance colonoscopies with biopsies every 1–5 years to screen for colorectal cancer starting 8–10 years after initial diagnosis of UC.

Key learning point: Ulcerative colitis significantly increases the risk of colorectal cancer, necessitating regular surveillance colonoscopies beginning 8–10 years after diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Colonic granulomas can develop in patients with Crohn disease (CD), an inflammatory bowel disease that also causes abdominal cramping and diarrhea. Colonic granulomas have low sensitivity but high specificity for CD. However, in CD, the rectum is usually spared and it mostly presents with watery, nonbloody stools and with just a slight increase in stool frequency as opposed to this patient showing bloody stools with mucus and a marked increase in stool frequency. Furthermore, right lower quadrant pain is more common in CD.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastric cancer has multiple risk factors, but ulcerative colitis, which this patient likely has, is not among them. Risk factors for gastric cancer include a diet rich in nitrates and salt, alcohol use, Helicobacter pylori infection, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic cancer has multiple risk factors, but ulcerative colitis, which this patient likely has, is not among them. Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include smoking, heavy alcohol consumption, chronic pancreatitis, and inherited genetic syndromes.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a thrombotic microangiopathy and complication of diarrheal bacterial infection, particularly with enterohemorrhagic E. coli. Though this patient has a 1-month history of diarrhea, the typical presentation of HUS is the triad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and impaired renal function that develops 5–10 days after the onset of diarrheal illness. Additionally, HUS typically affects young children.
questions.hint: If a biopsy were conducted, histopathology would show mucosal and submucosal inflammation with crypt abscesses.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of increasing generalized fatigue. For the past 5 weeks, he has also experienced mild cramping lower abdominal pain and occasional bloody diarrhea. Vital signs are normal. On examination, his abdomen is soft and nondistended with mild tenderness over the lower quadrants bilaterally. Rectal examination reveals stool mixed with blood. Laboratory studies are within reference ranges. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Colonoscopy with biopsy is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of IBD. In contrast to CD, which may affect the entire gastrointestinal tract but typically spares the rectum, UC usually affects only the colon and rectum in a continuous pattern. Typical macroscopic findings in UC include an inflamed, reddened mucosa, bleeding on contact with the endoscope, fibrin-covered ulcers, and loss of vascular markings. Histological findings include granulocyte infiltration to the mucosa and submucosa, crypt abscesses, and, in advanced disease, mucosal atrophy and epithelial dysplasia.

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in patients with features of acute severe disease, defined as > 6 bloody stools per day and/or signs of systemic toxicity (fever, tachycardia, anemia, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate), because of an increased risk of bowel perforation. Instead, a lower endoscopy (sigmoidoscopy) may be attempted to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment. In these patients, a full colonoscopy should be performed once their condition has improved.

Key learning point: Colonoscopy with biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing inflammatory bowel disease and assessing disease extent, unless acute severe disease is present.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the sigmoid colon

The mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Several linear, semi-confluent ulcerations (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy may be used to evaluate for IBD and is the diagnostic test of choice in patients with acute severe disease who have an increased risk of bowel perforation. As this patient has features of mild IBD (e.g., mild abdominal pain; no fever, tachycardia, or anemia; normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and requires evaluation of the entire colon to assess the extent of disease, sigmoidoscopy is not the most appropriate initial test.

C) INCORRECT:

A D-xylose absorption test is indicated to diagnose malabsorption syndrome, which may be caused by disorders such as celiac disease, Whipple disease, or IBD and manifests with fatigue, chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. However, this patient does not have steatorrhea or weight loss, which makes malabsorption unlikely. Additionally, a D-xylose absorption test is neither routinely conducted nor recommended as an initial test if there is a strong suspicion of UC.

D) INCORRECT:

Although capsule endoscopy may help to visualize typical lesions of UC, its role in the diagnosis of the disease is limited because it does not allow tissue samples to be taken for biopsy.

Capsule endoscopy may be used in cases of obscure gastrointestinal bleeding. Although this patient presents with bloody diarrhea, he also has fatigue, abdominal pain, and elevated inflammatory markers, which are more suggestive of UC.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis can be useful for differentiating between UC and CD. However, it is neither routinely conducted nor recommended as an initial test if there is a strong suspicion of UC.

Although the role of CT in the diagnosis of uncomplicated UC is limited, this imaging modality is helpful for diagnosing complications associated with this disease (e.g., toxic megacolon, perforation).
questions.hint: This patient has findings suggestive of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Although the two principal types of IBD, Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), have similar features, the presence of bloody diarrhea indicates UC as the most likely cause of symptoms. CD rarely manifests with bloody diarrhea and is more often associated with weight loss and malnourishment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a 5-year history of ulcerative colitis presents with a 4-day history of increasing bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramping. He reports 7 bloody bowel movements in the past 24 hours and notes increasing fatigue. Vital signs are BP, 110/75; P, 99; R, 20; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL, white blood cell count 12,000/μL, platelets 450,000/μL, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 38 mm/hour, and C-reactive protein 28 mg/L. Abdominal x-ray shows loss of haustral markings but no bowel dilatation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT abdomen/pelvis and start broad-spectrum antibiotics
Discharge with oral prednisone and gastroenterology follow-up
Initiate oral mesalamine therapy and schedule outpatient sigmoidoscopy
Perform immediate flexible sigmoidoscopy in the emergency department
Admit for intravenous corticosteroids and gastroenterology consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT may be indicated if complications are suspected, but this patient shows no signs of perforation or obstruction. Empiric antibiotics are not routinely indicated in acute severe ulcerative colitis and may increase the risk of complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are insufficient for acute severe ulcerative colitis. This patient's presentation with ≥ 6 bowel movements daily and systemic signs of inflammation requires inpatient management.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral mesalamine is first-line therapy for mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis but is inadequate for acute severe disease. This patient has systemic signs of inflammation, indicating a severe flare that requires more aggressive therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy should be performed urgently but not immediately and is not performed in the ED. Gastroenterology should arrange the procedure within 24 hours as part of inpatient management to assess disease severity and guide treatment decisions.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient meets criteria for acute severe ulcerative colitis, with ≥ 6 bloody bowel movements daily plus indicators of systemic inflammation (fever, tachycardia, hemoglobin < 10.5 g/dL, and/or ESR > 30 mm/hour). Management involves hospital admission for IV corticosteroids, supportive care, and urgent gastroenterology consultation for sigmoidoscopy within 24 hours.

questions.text: A 24-year-old graduate student presents with a 6-week history of crampy lower abdominal pain and up to 10 episodes of bloody diarrhea daily. He reports urgency and a sensation of incomplete evacuation. He has also noted unintentional weight loss and fatigue. On examination, he has mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant. In addition to his gastrointestinal complaints, which of the following findings is most likely to be discovered during a comprehensive physical examination?

choices.text: Jaundice and prominent superficial abdominal veins
Draining tracts and skin tags in the perianal region
Painful, red nodules over the anterior lower legs
Symmetric swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints
Erythematous facial rash sparing the nasolabial folds

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Jaundice and prominent superficial abdominal veins (caput medusae) suggest cirrhosis with portal hypertension, which can be a complication of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Although PSC is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis, it is a rare extraintestinal manifestation. Furthermore, it would be atypical for a young patient to present with signs of decompensated liver disease concurrently with their initial colitis symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Draining tracts and skin tags in the perianal region describe perianal disease, which includes fistulas, fissures, and abscesses. This is a hallmark of Crohn disease, which is characterized by transmural inflammation that can penetrate the bowel wall and create tracts to other structures. Ulcerative colitis, which this patient likely has, involves only the mucosal and submucosal layers and rarely causes perianal fistulizing disease.

C) CORRECT:

Erythema nodosum, a form of panniculitis (inflammation of subcutaneous fat), is one of the most common extraintestinal manifestations of inflammatory bowel disease, including ulcerative colitis. These tender, erythematous nodules typically appear on the anterior shins. The activity of erythema nodosum often parallels the activity of the underlying bowel disease, meaning it flares during periods of active colitis. Other common extraintestinal manifestations that often correlate with disease activity include peripheral arthritis, episcleritis, and aphthous ulcers.

D) INCORRECT:

While arthritis is a common extraintestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease, it typically presents as an asymmetric, non-erosive oligoarthritis affecting large joints like the knees and ankles. Symmetric, polyarticular involvement of small joints, such as the metacarpophalangeal joints, is the characteristic pattern of rheumatoid arthritis, a distinct autoimmune condition.

E) INCORRECT:

A malar or "butterfly" rash is a typical feture of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). While SLE is an autoimmune condition and can present with systemic and gastrointestinal symptoms, this specific rash is not a recognized extraintestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The patient's primary symptoms are consistent with IBD.
questions.hint: The patient's presentation with bloody diarrhea, urgency, and tenesmus suggests inflammation that is confined to the colon and rectum. Consider the most common extraintestinal manifestations associated with this type of inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider with a 4-month history of intermittent, bloody diarrhea, crampy lower abdominal pain, and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) unintentional weight loss. She also reports increased fatigue. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Laboratory results show a hemoglobin of 11.2 g/dL and an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) level. Stool studies for infectious etiologies, including Clostridium difficile, are negative. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Serologic testing for ASCA and p-ANCA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fecal calprotectin is a non-invasive marker of intestinal inflammation. While it is useful for differentiating IBD from non-inflammatory conditions like irritable bowel syndrome, this patient already has objective evidence of inflammation (elevated CRP, anemia) and alarm features (bloody diarrhea, weight loss). A fecal calprotectin test would be expected to be elevated but would not provide a definitive diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) and perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are associated with Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis, respectively. However, their sensitivity and specificity are too low to be used for primary diagnosis. They cannot confirm or rule out IBD and are sometimes used as adjunctive tests to help differentiate between IBD subtypes after a diagnosis has already been established.

C) INCORRECT:

CT enterography is a valuable imaging study for evaluating the small bowel and identifying extraluminal complications of IBD, such as strictures, fistulas, or abscesses, which are more common in Crohn disease. However, it is not the initial test for establishing a definitive diagnosis, as it does not allow for direct mucosal visualization or tissue sampling.

D) INCORRECT:

Video capsule endoscopy is a tool used to visualize the small bowel mucosa, which is useful when suspecting Crohn disease confined to the small bowel. However, it is not the initial test for a patient with signs of ulcerative colitis. Furthermore, it is contraindicated if there is a suspicion of a stricture, which can occur in IBD, as the capsule can become retained. This procedure does not allow for biopsies.

E) CORRECT:

Ileocolonoscopy is the gold standard for establishing a new diagnosis of IBD. It allows for direct visualization of the colonic mucosa to assess the extent and pattern of inflammation (e.g., continuous versus skip lesions) and to evaluate the terminal ileum. Most importantly, it permits biopsy of affected tissue, which is essential for histopathologic confirmation of the diagnosis and to differentiate between ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease. Histopathology findings of IBD include crypt abscesses and noncaseating granulomas.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is highly suspicious for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), likely ulcerative colitis, given the bloody diarrhea and left lower quadrant pain.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of intermittent, bloody diarrhea. She reports having three to four loose stools daily, often with urgency and mild lower abdominal cramping. She denies fever, significant weight loss, or nocturnal symptoms. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies show a normal hemoglobin and C-reactive protein level. A recent flexible sigmoidoscopy demonstrated continuous mucosal erythema and friability limited to the rectum. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While sulfasalazine is an oral 5-ASA medication used for ulcerative colitis, it is generally considered a second-line option to other medications due to a higher incidence of side effects related to its sulfa component.

B) CORRECT:

For mild-to-moderate ulcerative proctitis, topical 5-aminosalicylic acid agents (5-ASA) like mesalamine are the first-line therapy for inducing remission. Topical therapy (suppositories or enemas) delivers high concentrations of the anti-inflammatory drug directly to the diseased mucosa, which is more effective than oral therapy and minimizes systemic absorption and side effects. Mesalamine is thought to work by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins and leukotrienes in the gut.

C) INCORRECT:

Loperamide is an anti-motility agent that can provide symptomatic relief from diarrhea, but does not treat the underlying mucosal inflammation causing the symptoms. More importantly, its use is cautioned in active inflammatory bowel disease flares because it can decrease gut motility and potentially precipitate toxic megacolon, a life-threatening complication.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids like prednisone are used to induce remission in patients with moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis. This patient's presentation, including a low stool frequency, stable vital signs, and normal inflammatory markers, is consistent with mild disease. The significant systemic side effects associated with corticosteroids make them inappropriate as a first-line agent for mild, localized disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Infliximab is a biologic agent (an anti-TNF-alpha antibody) reserved for moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis that is refractory to other treatments or for patients who are steroid-dependent. Initiating biologic therapy is not indicated for a first presentation of mild, localized disease due to its potential side effects and the availability of safer, effective first-line options.
questions.hint: The patient's clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and the endoscopic findings confined to the rectum indicate mild ulcerative proctitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a six-week history of bloody diarrhea and lower abdominal cramping. He reports up to eight bowel movements per day, often with a sense of urgency and incomplete evacuation. He has lost 5 kg (11 lb) unintentionally. He is a nonsmoker and has no significant family history of gastrointestinal disease. Vital signs are normal except for a heart rate of 105/min. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 10.8 g/dL and an elevated C-reactive protein. A colonoscopy is performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen?

choices.text: Multiple, raised, yellow-white plaques adherent to the colonic mucosa
Segmental inflammation with dusky, friable mucosa localized to the splenic flexure
Discontinuous, patchy ulcerations with areas of normal-appearing mucosa
Continuous, circumferential erythema and friability extending proximally from the rectum
Linear, serpiginous ulcers with a cobblestone appearance in the terminal ileum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These findings describe pseudomembranes, which are pathognomonic for Clostridioides difficile colitis. Although C. difficile can cause bloody diarrhea, it is most often associated with recent antibiotic use, hospitalization, or advanced age. The six-week duration of symptoms and lack of risk factors make this diagnosis less probable.

B) INCORRECT:

This finding is characteristic of ischemic colitis, which typically affects watershed areas of colonic blood supply, such as the splenic flexure. Ischemic colitis is uncommon in a young, healthy 28-year-old man and usually manifests more acutely with severe abdominal pain followed by bloody diarrhea. This patient's six-week history makes an ischemic cause less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes the characteristic "skip lesions" of Crohn disease. Although Crohn disease is a major differential diagnosis for inflammatory bowel disease, this patient's prominent bloody diarrhea and symptoms of proctitis (urgency, tenesmus) are more typical of a different condition.

D) CORRECT:

The key endoscopic features of UC are inflammation that invariably begins in the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous and circumferential manner. The inflammation is limited to the mucosa and submucosa, resulting in diffuse erythema, edema, friability (easy bleeding on contact), and loss of the normal vascular pattern. This patient's symptoms of bloody diarrhea, urgency, and tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete evacuation) are direct consequences of this rectosigmoid inflammation. The left lower quadrant tenderness corresponds to the typical area of involvement.

E) INCORRECT:

These findings are classic for Crohn disease, resulting from transmural inflammation that creates deep, longitudinal ulcers and intervening areas of edematous mucosa. Although Crohn disease is a consideration, this patient's symptoms of tenesmus and left lower quadrant pain suggest rectosigmoid disease, whereas terminal ileum involvement typically causes right lower quadrant pain.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of bloody diarrhea, tenesmus, and left lower quadrant pain strongly suggests ulcerative colitis (UC).
